Comment: This is my first annotation. I chose this game because I was losing at some point but I didn't give up and in the end I managed to make my opponent resign. Victory is sweeter when you work hard for it and the opponent has a higher rating :)
The Slav Defense.
The Slav Defense.
The Slav Defense.
Slav Accepted. I take an undefended pawn, but in fact I don't have great hopes of holding on to mine on c4.
Slav Accepted. I take an undefended pawn, but in fact I don't have great hopes of holding on to mine on c4.
Slav Accepted. I take an undefended pawn, but in fact I don't have great hopes of holding on to mine on c4.
Slav Accepted. I take an undefended pawn, but in fact I don't have great hopes of holding on to mine on c4.
White should have played 5. a4 first (the Alapin Variation) in order to prevent me from defending the c4 pawn with b5.
I am able to protect my extra pawn, after all, but the c6 pawn supporting the other two is only defended by my undeveloped knight. I would like to get rid of the white knight on e5.
What I see is that wkhlt is increasing pressure on my c4 pawn. What I fail to see is that he also opens the way for his queen.
I wouldn't mind a knight exchange. Also, I can move f6 to threaten his other knight.
His queen threatens a mate at f7 and would also have c3 in her range, if it weren't for my knight.
What I had been planning to do. It prevents the mate but gets me into more trouble.
Forced.
Forced.

I could have perhaps avoided losing the rook with Rg8, but in blitz chess I had less time to think than I have now, writing these comments. I was desperate to avoid a discovered check, so I chose to take his knight.
One more mistake on my part. Thinking I'm placing the bishop on a good square and defending my g6 pawn, I give him the opportunity to fork my bishop and knight.
One more mistake on my part. Thinking I'm placing the bishop on a good square and defending my g6 pawn, I give him the opportunity to fork my bishop and knight.
One more mistake on my part. Thinking I'm placing the bishop on a good square and defending my g6 pawn, I give him the opportunity to fork my bishop and knight.
After all, I only lost a pawn because of the careless bishop move. But as a consequence he almost got his promoted!
After all, I only lost a pawn because of the careless bishop move. But as a consequence he almost got his promoted!
After all, I only lost a pawn because of the careless bishop move. But as a consequence he almost got his promoted!
After all, I only lost a pawn because of the careless bishop move. But as a consequence he almost got his promoted!
He's putting pressure on my already shattered kingside.

Counter-attack! After gambiting his c pawn, exchanging his knight on c3 and attacking with his queen and dark-squared bishop, his king is rather unprotected. I'm also making room for castling queenside.
I protect my bishop and prepare to castle.
I protect my bishop and prepare to castle.
His dark-squared bishop was the only thing preventing my queen from going to d2. He chooses to exchange it though, probably hoping to promote his pawn.
And here she goes! Pushing wkhlt's king into the murky waters in the middle of the board.
And here she goes! Pushing wkhlt's king into the murky waters in the middle of the board.
And here she goes! Pushing wkhlt's king into the murky waters in the middle of the board.
I won a pawn in the process, but now I cannot check any more. I hurry to move my king to safety.

I threaten check with Qxf4 and hope that I'll be able to somehow go on checking him, even after he promotes his pawn. Taking a second look at it now, I'm wondering what I could have possibly done after 21. g8=Q Qxf4+ 22. Kh5, except taking his second queen with my rook...
